title: Derby 4 Wolves 2 - Report and pictures
text:
Tweet 
Chris Martin scored twice - opening the scoring in the third minute as Wolves made a sluggish start - and also saw a penalty saved by Emiliano Martinez as Derby threatened to run riot. 
Some shoddy defending from Wolves contributed heavily to the defeat, with Martinez at fault for Martin's second when he failed to claim a Bradley Johnson cross. 
Johnson himself scored Derby's third with Wolves unable to clear a corner, although the scoreline was made respectable by Adam Le Fondre's second half goal to bring it back to 4-2, after Johnny Russell had increased Derby's lead after the break. 
Earlier, Benik Afobe had restored parity with a Wolves equaliser at 1-1, sending a thumping shot past Scott Carson from James Henry's clever corner. 
But Wolves, for the second time in 12 months after Derby thrashed them 5-0 at the iPro last season, were comfortably outclassed by the East Midlands side. What do you think? Log in and start commenting 
Paul Clement's rampant team were sharper in attack, with Wolves' young defence struggling to cope in what was a reality check after successive 3-0 victories before the international break. 
Jackett made one change from the side that had beaten Huddersfield 3-0 before the international break, replacing Sheyi Ojo with Jed Wallace. 
There was a boisterous atmosphere before kick off with a near-full iPro a sea of scarves after 24,000 were handed out to fans in the build-up to the game. 
And if the noise was intended to get Derby flying out of the traps it certainly worked as they took the lead inside three minutes. 
The ball was worked to Martin outside the box and his rasping effort flew into the top corner, leaving Martinez no chance. 
The goal will have had some Wolves fans fearing a repeat of last season's 5-0 thrashing and those concerns will have increased when former Albion midfielder George Thorne got behind a thumping 25-yard volley which Martinez beat away. 
Attacks were few and far between in the opening stages for Wolves. 
But out of the blue they equalised with a superb strike from Afobe. 
In a pre-worked move, Henry sent a low corner towards the penalty spot where Afobe lashed past Scott Carson with a rasping shot. 
Derby responded instantly and Martinez was again called upon, saving a Martin shot on the turn. Adam Le Fondre of Wolverhampton Wanderers celebrates after scoring a goal to make it 4-2 
Back came Wolves and from a Henry cross Adam Le Fondre could have made it 2-1, but ex-Wolves defender Jason Shackell blocked his goalbound effort. 
And just three minutes later Derby made Wolves pay by re-taking the lead. 
It was a howler from a Wolves point of view - Dominic Iorfa's poor clearance gave Derby the ball back and from Johnson's cross Martin beat Martinez to the ball and nodded home. 
The goal was a carbon copy of Kenwyne Jones' header at Cardiff in August, with the keeper in no-man's land as Kortney Hause left the cross, presumably after getting a shout from the Argentine. 
Henry was Wolves' most creative outlet by a distance, tormenting Derby left-back Craig Forstyth, but from another excellent cross Derby cleared their lines with no one there to tap home. 
The game was meandering gently towards half time but then in stoppage time Derby won a penalty, with Batth clearly taking out Thomas Ince in the box. 
The captain earned a booking, but Martinez redeemed himself by saving his second penalty of the season to deny Martin a hat-trick. 
However just seconds later his good work was undone when Derby made it 3-1, with dreadful defending allowing a corner to hit Johnson and trickle into the net past the statuesque goalkeeper. 
Wolves were unchanged at half time and indeed little changed on the field with Derby carrying on where they left off. Kevin McDonald of Wolverhampton Wanderers 
Russell coasted past Hause and shot at Martinez, before a Hendrick free kick hit the wall. 
It was all Derby and on 57 minutes they scored yet again. Wolves were picked apart at the back and Scott Golbourne's block from near his own goal line fell to Russell, who fired into the corner. 
Wolves were shellshocked and their priority suddenly became keeping the score down with as succession of shots blocked as the visitors struggled to cope with the Derby onslaught. 
Jackett reacted by replacing Wallace and Jack Price with Sheyi Ojo and Conor Coady. 
And like in his previous two substitute appearances against Preston and Fulham, Ojo made an immediate impact, teeing up Le Fondre with a header and the on-loan striker smartly beat Carson from close range. 
It was a goal from nowhere that gave Wolves faint hope. 
But any Wolves fans expecting a rousing finish were to be disappointed - they barely tested Carson again, with Derby looking the more likely scorers. 
Russell, a constant menace, forced a late save from Martinez as the game petered out in the closing minutes. 
With eight minutes left Jackett sent on teenager Bright Enobakhare in place of Le Fondre, but the game was long gone with Wolves unable to make any headway. 
DERBY: Carson; Christie (Baird, 79), Keogh, Shackell, Forsyth; Ince, Thorne, Hendrick (Butterfield, 74), Johnson, Russell; Martin (Bent, 90). Subs: Grant, Warnock, Shotton, Weimann. 
Goals: Martin (3, 28), Johnson (45), Russell (57). More on this story: 
WOLVES: Martinez; Iorfa, Batth, Hause, Golbourne; Henry, McDonald, Price (Coady, 62), Wallace (Ojo, 62); Afobe; Le Fondre (Enobakhare, 82). Subs: Ikeme, Doherty, Van La Parra, Byrne.
